facts.text: Appellants owned two motor trucks: No. AWB 230 V-8 Ford 1938 Model and No. AWB 253 Oldsmobile Model 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carried on business in partnership in the firm name and style of Ishwarsing Dhiansingh and were the owners of two motor trucks, one bearing No. AWB 230  V-8 Ford 1938 Model  and the other bearing No. AWB 253  Oldsmobile Model 1938 .

facts.text: On May 4, 1942, appellants entered into agreement hiring out trucks to respondent for Rs. 17 per day per truck, terminable on one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1942, the appellants entered into an agreement for the hiring out of these trucks to the respondent for imparting tuition to the military personnel. Rupees 17 per day per truck was stipulated as the hire and the agreement was terminable on one months numberice by either side.

facts.text: Truck No. AWB 230 handed over to respondent on April 29, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the said agreement truck No. AWB 230 was handed over to the respondent on April 29, 1942, and truck No. AWB 253 was given on May 4, 1942.

facts.text: Truck No. AWB 253 handed over to respondent on May 4, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the said agreement truck No. AWB 230 was handed over to the respondent on April 29, 1942, and truck No. AWB 253 was given on May 4, 1942.

facts.text: Respondent gave notice on June 29, 1942, terminating agreement effective August 1, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1942, the respondent gave numberice to the appellants terminating the agreement with effect from August 1, 1942, and asked them to remove the trucks on the expiration of that period.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 attended Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee on August 1, 1942 at 9 a.m. to remove trucks, but not delivered.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 1 attended upon the Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee at about 9 a.m. on August 1, 1942, for removing the trucks but they were number delivered to him by the transport in-charge

facts.text: Respondent did not return trucks nor pay hire charges.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number return the trucks to the Appellants number did it pay any hire charges to them.

facts.text: Respondent claimed trucks delivered to Surjan Singh, alleged partner of appellants, and hire paid to him.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took up the position that the amount of hire had been paid and the trucks had been delivered by it to one Surjan Singh who was alleged to have been a partner of the appellants

facts.text: Appellants denied Surjan Singh was partner and claimed liability for hire and return of trucks.

anchor.surface_text: and thus entitled to receive the said payment and the delivery of the trucks in question. The appellants companytroverted the said position and claimed that the respondent was liable to pay the hire money as well as return the trucks to them.

facts.text: Appellants gave notice under s.80 CPC on August 4, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1942, the appellants gave the requisite numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure to the respondent and claimed  i  the hire money up to July 31, 1942,

facts.text: Suit filed by appellants on January 8, 1943 against respondent and Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent failed and neglected to companyply with the requisitions companyained in the said letter with the result that on January 8, 1943, the appellants filed a suit against the respondent and the said Surjan Singh

facts.text: Trial Court: Court of Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur, Civil Suit No. 10-B of 1943, decree dated July 7, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948, of the Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 27 of 1954 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 7, 1944, of the Court of Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur, in Civil Suit No. 10-B of 1943.

facts.text: Trial Court held respondent not justified in delivering trucks to Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the respondent was number justified in paying the rent and delivering the trucks to the said Surjan Singh.

facts.text: Trial Court awarded Rs. 3,500 as price of trucks, interest at 6%, rent Rs. 2,380 with interest, total Rs. 6,032-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: It awarded to the appellants the price of the two trucks which had been fixed by the appellants at Rs. 3,500 both in the numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the evidence led on their behalf. It also awarded to the appellants interest on that sum at 6 per annum by way of damages. ... total Rs. 6,032-4-0

facts.text: High Court appeal: First Appeal No. 27 of 1954, judgment April 7, 1948, enhanced decree by Rs. 5,953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948, of the Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 27 of 1954

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1954, heard October 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948, of the Nagpur High Court ... 1957. October 29.

facts.text: High Court disallowed higher value claim beyond Rs. 3,500 based on s.80 notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disallowed the appellants claim for the higher value of the trucks on the ground that the appellants had merely claimed Rs. 3,500 as the price of the said trucks in the numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit is for wrongful detention (detinue), not conversion.

anchor.surface_text: they elected to have the said trucks re-delivered to them and asked for the specific delivery thereof and filed their action for wrongful detention of the said trucks. They were, in our opinion, perfectly entitled to do so

facts.text: Supreme Court awarded Rs. 7,000 as value of trucks at date of judgment.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants were entitled to recover from the respondent the value of the said trucks which, as has been already stated, was Rs. 7,000 in the alternative

facts.text: Supreme Court awarded additional Rs. 6,457 damages for wrongful detention at Rs.17/day/truck for approx. 1 year.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants would therefore be entitled to recover over and above the sum of Rs. 5,953 already awarded to them by the High Court an additional sum of Rs. 6,457 by way of damages for wrongful detention

anchor.surface_text: It would be relevant to consider what is the exact scope of the two forms of action, viz., action for wrongful conversion and action for wrongful detention, otherwise known as action in trover and action in detinue. A conversion is an act of wilful interference, without lawful justification, with any chattel in a manner inconsistent with the right of another, whereby that other is deprived of the use and possession of it.

holdings.text: A bailor is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or for wrongful detention thereof notwithstanding that the bailee may have wrongfully parted with possession earlier.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that a bailor in the event of the non- delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him in that behalf is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or the wrongful detention thereof

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court follows English precedents like Reeve v. Palmer, Wilkinson v. Verity; bailee cannot take advantage of own wrong; election is plaintiff's choice.

holdings.text: The defendant bailee cannot contend that the plaintiff bailor knew or ought to have known of the conversion and therefore must sue only in conversion; he cannot take advantage of his own wrong.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant cannot be heard to say that the plaintiff knew or ought to have known of the conversion of the goods by him and therefore should pursue his remedy only in conversion. He cannot take advantage of his own wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed from Reeve v. Palmer (1858) and Wilkinson v. Verity; longstanding principle that bailee liable in detinue despite prior misconduct.

holdings.text: The appellants' suit is properly one for wrongful detention (detinue); they were entitled to elect this remedy despite knowledge of delivery to Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: they elected to have the said trucks re-delivered to them and asked for the specific delivery thereof and filed their action for wrongful detention of the said trucks. They were, in our opinion, perfectly entitled to do so

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff elected detinue; immediate demand on termination date; no waiver of conversion.

holdings.text: Strict compliance with s.80 CPC notice does not require pedantic scrutiny; common sense reading suffices; notice adequately claimed value at then-date, allowing suit claim for value at decree date.

anchor.surface_text: We are constrained to observe that the approach of the High Court to this question was not well founded... A common sense reading of the notice under s. 80 would lead any Court to the conclusion that the strict requirements of that section had been complied with

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Privy Council strictness; imports common sense per Pollock CB, Beaumont CJ; notice demanded delivery or then-value Rs.3500, suit reserves higher.

holdings.text: There was no delay by appellants in filing suit that would indicate intent to speculate on rising market.

anchor.surface_text: There was no delay on the part of the appellants which would spell out any intention on their part to take advantage of the rising market

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit filed promptly after s.80 expiry (Jan 8, 1943); no evidence of market rise in interim; notice claimed specific delivery.

holdings.text: In action for wrongful detention (detinue), alternative value of goods is assessed at date of judgment/decree, not date of tort or demand refusal.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the appellants were entitled to recover from the respondent the value of the said trucks which, as has been already stated, was Rs. 7,000 in the alternative

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Rosenthal v. Alderton (1946 CA); detinue is continuing tort asserting title till delivery; contrasts with conversion (tort complete at interference).

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow this appeal and pass in favour of the appellants, in addition to the enhanced decree which they have already obtained from the High Court, a decree against the respondent for Rs. 3,500 being the appreciated value of the said trucks together with interest thereon at 6 per annum from July 7, 1944, till this date as also for a sum of Rs. 6,457 by way of additional damages for wrongful detention of the said trucks,

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. Additional decree for Rs. 3,500 (appreciated value of trucks) with 6% interest from July 7, 1944 till judgment date; Rs. 6,457 additional damages for wrongful detention; additional proportionate costs in Trial Court and High Court; costs of appeal.
